title: Can a blood test detect endometriosis early? Why a new study holds out hope - The Indian Express
summary:
Can a blood test detect endometriosis early? Why a new study holds out hope

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Indian Express

Australian researchers have developed a novel blood test that can detect endometriosis in its early stages. This non-invasive approach aims to reduce long diagnosis times and costly procedures.

  • The study identified 10 protein biomarkers in blood.
  • Endometriosis is a significant issue among Indian women, leading to infertility and chronic pain.
  • The blood test could encourage diagnosis in conservative communities where invasive procedures face resistance.
  • Around 25-30% of Indian women of reproductive age may be affected by endometriosis.
  • The late diagnosis can result in severe health consequences and a long delay in treatment.
“Such a test, once approved for use, can also help with detection in places where advanced medical facilities are scarce.” - Dr. Neelam Suri

The findings from this research could transform diagnostic approaches, offering hope for better management of endometriosis.
newTitle: Can a blood test detect endometriosis early? Why a new study holds out hope

title: Researchers uncover critical mutations in H5N1 bird flu strain from infected Texan - Down To Earth Magazine
summary:
Critical Mutations Found in H5N1 Bird Flu Strain from Texas

Published on: 18 Jan 2025, 6:53 am

A recent study has discovered unique mutations in an H5N1 avian influenza strain isolated from a human patient in Texas, raising concerns about the virus's potential to evolve and spread among humans.

  • Researchers identified nine mutations in the H5N1 strain from a Texas patient that are absent in strains found in cattle.
  • This strain, designated H5N1 HPhTX, demonstrates enhanced replication in human cells and increased disease severity in mice.
  • Since early 2024, the H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b has impacted approximately 928 dairy herds, infected 67 humans, and caused mass bird fatalities.
  • The human case in Texas was linked to contact with infected milk.
  • There are concerns that the virus could evolve to transmit between humans, with a previous study indicating it’s close to being transmissible.
  • US antiviral treatments remain effective against both the human and bovine strains of the virus.
“The clock is ticking for the virus to evolve to more easily infect and potentially transmit from human to human, which would be a concern.” - Professor Luis Martinez-Sobrido

In conclusion, continued monitoring of H5N1 strains and efforts to eradicate the virus in cattle populations are essential to mitigate public health risks caused by this evolving threat.
newTitle: Critical Mutations Found in H5N1 Bird Flu Strain from Texas

title: Evaluation of the adherence of municipalities and states to the Ministry of Health’s microplanning for high-quality vaccination activities and the increase in vaccination coverage in Brazil - BMC Public Health
Ayurveda can provide new hope for Alzheimer's, shows study conducted by Indian scientists - indiablooms
Molecular epidemiology of extended-spectrum beta-lactamases and carbapenemases-producing Shigella in Africa: a systematic review and meta-analysis - BMC Infectious Diseases
summary:
Molecular Epidemiology of Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamases and Carbapenemases-Producing Shigella in Africa: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

Published: 18 January 2025 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This systematic review investigates the molecular epidemiology of the extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) and carbapenemases-producing Shigella in Africa, highlighting the significant public health challenge posed by these drug-resistant strains.

  • Only 18 out of 583 articles were included in the meta-analysis.
  • Overall prevalence of ESBL and CR-producing Shigella was 41.2%.
  • Shigella flexneri was the most prevalent species at 34.5%.
  • The most common resistance genes found were blaTEM, blaOXA−1, and blaCTX−M.
  • The prevalence of carbapenemases was low (<1%).
This study highlighted Shigella flexneri as the most prevalent ESBL and CR-producing Shigella species found in various African countries. The findings indicate that ESBL and CR-producing Shigella pose a significant public health threat in Africa.

Currently, monitoring and managing multidrug-resistant Shigella infections is urgent to improve public health outcomes.
newTitle: Molecular Epidemiology of Drug-Resistant Shigella in Africa: A Systematic Review

title: Rise in disease outbreaks alarms Africa CDC; cholera tops list of killers - Daijiworld.com
US providing Moderna $590 mn to speed mRNA pandemic for bird flu which experts fear may start a pandemic - The Economic Times
summary:
US providing Moderna $590 mn to speed mRNA pandemic for bird flu which experts fear may start a pandemic

Publication Date: Jan 18, 2025, Source: AFP

US health officials announced funding to advance the development of mRNA vaccines targeting the H5N1 bird flu virus, as fears grow of a potential pandemic. The initiative aims to enhance preparedness against emerging infectious diseases.

  • The US is awarding $590 million to Moderna for mRNA vaccine development.
  • This funding builds upon a previous $176 million awarded in July 2024.
  • Health officials express concern over the potential mutation of H5N1 into a more contagious form.
  • Since the outbreak began, 67 infections have been reported in the US, with the first death recorded recently.
“That is why this response has been a top priority for the Biden-Harris Administration and HHS,” said HHS Secretary Xavier Becerra.

The funding comes as global health officials remain vigilant about the emergence of bird flu variants that could pose significant threats to human health.
newTitle: US Funds Moderna $590 Million to Develop Bird Flu mRNA Vaccine Amid Pandemic Concerns

title: Health warnings about alcohol give only half the story - Hindustan Times
summary:
Health Warnings About Alcohol Give Only Half the Story

Publication Date: Jan 18, 2025 08:00 AM IST

Source: The Economist

The article discusses the mixed messages around alcohol consumption, balancing enjoyment against associated health risks. It highlights rising public health warnings against drinking while acknowledging the pleasure some find in moderate consumption.

  • “Dry January” campaign sees a third of British men attempting sobriety.
  • Surgeon General Vivek Murthy suggests warning labels on alcohol.
  • WHO states there is “no safe level” of alcohol consumption.
  • Moderate drinking may have heart health benefits, according to recent findings.
  • Canadians now define low risk as one-in-1,000 chance of premature death from alcohol.
“If one bit of public-health advice seems absurd, people may start to doubt other bits, too.”

In conclusion, while heavy drinking is harmful, the article argues for a balanced view that considers both the risks and the enjoyment of alcohol consumption.
newTitle: Health Warnings About Alcohol Give Only Half the Story

title: High levels of stress hormone Cortisol can be damaging. Here's how to manage it - India Today
Africa reports over 200 disease outbreaks in 2024 - Social News XYZ
summary:
Africa Reports Over 200 Disease Outbreaks in 2024

Date: January 18, 2024 | Source: Social News XYZ

The Africa CDC has raised alarm over a sharp rise in public health emergencies across the continent, reporting over 200 disease outbreaks in 2024.

  • In 2024, 213 disease outbreaks were reported, compared to 166 in 2023.
  • The top five high-burden diseases include cholera, measles, dengue, mpox, and diphtheria.
  • Cholera resulted in approximately 204,115 cases and 3,747 deaths in 2024.
  • Measles accounted for 234,320 cases and 3,220 deaths in the same year.
  • Mpox led to 77,888 cases and 1,321 deaths across 21 countries.
“We see that the number of disease outbreaks in 2024 was more than in 2023... We hope that this year will be different from the last year,” said Africa CDC Director-General Jean Kaseya.

The Africa CDC is calling for significant investment in laboratory infrastructure and local vaccine production to better manage health emergencies.
newTitle: Africa Reports Over 200 Disease Outbreaks in 2024

title: Health News Live January 18, 2025 : Say no to sugar in coffee! Study shows unsweetened coffee reduces Alzheimer's disease risk by 30% - Hindustan Times
Say no to sugar in coffee! Study shows unsweetened coffee reduces Alzheimer's disease risk by 30% - Hindustan Times
summary:
Say No to Sugar in Coffee: Study Shows Unsweetened Coffee Reduces Alzheimer's Disease Risk by 30%

Published Date: January 18, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

This article discusses a study that links unsweetened coffee consumption with significantly reduced risks of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. The findings indicate that unsweetened coffee drinkers have a 29-30% reduced risk of developing these neurodegenerative diseases.

  • The study analyzed data from over 200,000 participants aged 40 to 69.
  • Finding: Unsweetened coffee drinkers had a 29-30% lower risk of Alzheimer’s.
  • There was also a 43% lower risk of dying from Alzheimer’s and related conditions.
  • Decaf coffee reduced risks by 34-37% and lowered dying risks by 47%.
  • Adding sugar or sweeteners to coffee offers no significant health benefits.
“Every dietary choice matters in the long run.”

The results emphasize the importance of dietary choices, particularly regarding sugar consumption, for brain health.
newTitle: Say No to Sugar in Coffee: Study Shows Unsweetened Coffee Reduces Alzheimer's Disease Risk by 30%

Integrating malaria vaccine and CRISPR/Cas9 gene drive: a comprehensive strategy for accelerated malaria eradication - Malaria Journal
summary:
Integrating malaria vaccine and CRISPR/Cas9 gene drive: a comprehensive strategy for accelerated malaria eradication

Date: 17 January 2025 | Source: Malaria Journal

Malaria continues to be a formidable public health challenge, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. This article reviews the integration of CRISPR/Cas9 gene drive technology with malaria vaccination efforts to enhance vector control and reduce transmission.

  • Recent advancements in malaria vaccines like RTS,S/AS01 and R21/Matrix-M™ are promising for prevention.
  • The paper discusses the potential for gene drive mechanisms to suppress and replace malaria-transmitting Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • Challenges such as regulatory hurdles, community acceptance, and funding are examined.
  • The integrated approach could significantly contribute to WHO's malaria reduction targets by 2030.
“The integration of malaria vaccination with CRISPR/Cas9 gene drive technology represents a promising dual approach that could significantly reduce malaria-associated morbidities and mortalities.”

This innovative strategy may revolutionize malaria control, addressing both biological complexities and socio-economic factors.
newTitle: Integrating Malaria Vaccine and CRISPR/Cas9 Gene Drive for Eradication Strategy

title: Health Rounds: New method may eliminate need for cold storage of drugs, vaccines - Reuters
summary:
Health Rounds: New method may eliminate need for cold storage of drugs, vaccines

Date: Jan 17 | Source: Reuters

A new storage technique can keep protein-based drugs and vaccines stable without refrigeration, potentially saving billions and increasing accessibility in resource-limited areas.

  • The technique utilizes a perfluorocarbon oil storage solution and surfactant to coat drug molecules.
  • It maintains stability at temperatures up to 212 degrees Fahrenheit (100°C).
  • This innovation could allow distribution in places without reliable refrigeration, including combat zones.
“Over 80% of biologic drugs and 90% of vaccines require temperature-controlled conditions” - Scott Medina, study leader at Pennsylvania State University.

The new method promises significant cost savings and wider access to life-saving medications, particularly in challenging environments.
newTitle: New Method Could Eliminate Cold Storage for Vital Drugs and Vaccines

title: Experts divided over HMPV threat, precautions remain key - Daily Pioneer
Roll out and prospects of the malaria vaccine R21/Matrix-M - PLOS
summary:
The Rollout and Future of the Malaria Vaccine R21/Matrix-M

Published: January 17, 2025 | Source: PLoS Medicine

In 2025, the malaria vaccine R21/Matrix-M, developed as an improvement over RTS,S, received licensing from WHO. This article explores the implications of its rollout amid the ongoing global malaria burden.

  • R21/Matrix-M is a new malaria vaccine licensed and WHO-prequalified within 6 years since its first description in 2017.
  • It offers a 78% efficacy against uncomplicated malaria in children aged 5 to 17 months from clinical trials.
  • The vaccine aims to expand protection beyond just young children, including older children and adults at risk of malaria.
  • Production challenges remain, although plans to increase manufacturing capacity have been established.
  • Strategies involving mass vaccination along with drug administration could significantly reduce malaria transmission.
“After decades of waiting, 2 malaria vaccines are now registered and licensed, adding a promising tool for the control and ultimately the elimination of malaria.”

The progress of R21/Matrix-M is vital in combating the increasing global malaria burden and calls for innovative distribution strategies to maximize its impact.
newTitle: The Rollout and Future of the Malaria Vaccine R21/Matrix-M

title: Study Reveals a Glass of Milk a Day Could Help Lower Women's Risk of Colorectal Cancer - Health.com
summary:
Study Reveals a Glass of Milk a Day Could Help Lower Women's Risk of Colorectal Cancer

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Health

Getting a glass of milk’s worth of calcium a day could lower colorectal cancer risk in women, a new study published in Nature Communications found.

  • Colorectal cancer is the fourth leading cause of cancer death for women and is becoming more common among those under 65.
  • The study found a daily intake of 300 milligrams of calcium from food, equivalent to an 8-ounce glass of milk, is linked to a 17% reduction in colorectal cancer risk.
  • Calcium's protective effect was similar in both dairy and non-dairy sources, as stated by Keren Papier, PhD.
  • The Million Women Study surveyed over 540,000 women about their diets and health over more than 16 years.
  • The research utilized Mendelian Randomization to analyze the link between calcium intake and cancer risk.
“The study’s findings were especially reassuring,” said Veronika Fedirko, PhD.

While there is evidence suggesting a healthy diet can reduce cancer risk, experts stress the importance of overall dietary habits and lifestyle choices in reducing colorectal cancer risk.
newTitle: Study Reveals a Glass of Milk a Day Could Help Lower Women's Risk of Colorectal Cancer

Superfood Spotlight: 5 Ways To Consider Grapefruit A Superfood - Mint
summary:
Superfood Spotlight: 5 Ways To Consider Grapefruit A Superfood

Publication Date: January 17, 2025 Source: Mint

Grapefruit is a nutrient-rich citrus superfood that enhances breakfast with its tangy flavor and provides health benefits through vitamins and antioxidants for overall wellness.

  • Rich Source of Vitamin C: Grapefruit enhances immunity, combats colds, and promotes healthy skin.
  • Weight Management: Low-calorie and high in fiber, grapefruit helps with weight maintenance or loss.
  • Packed with Antioxidants: Contains lycopene and flavonoids that fight oxidative stress.
  • Improves Heart Health: Potassium balances sodium and fiber reduces cholesterol.
  • Aids Digestion: Promotes digestive health and toxin elimination.
“Grapefruit, rich in water and dietary fiber, promotes digestive health, hydration, and toxin elimination.”

This article highlights the numerous health benefits of grapefruit, positioning it as a superfood that can easily be incorporated into daily diets.
newTitle: Superfood Spotlight: 5 Ways To Consider Grapefruit A Superfood

title: 73 cases of lumpy skin disease reported in Namibia - Social News XYZ
summary:
73 Cases of Lumpy Skin Disease Reported in Namibia

Date: January 17, 2025 Source: SocialNews.XYZ

The Directorate of Veterinary Services in Namibia has issued a warning following the confirmation of 73 cases of Lumpy Skin Disease (LSD) affecting cattle in the Otjombinde Constituency.

  • 73 confirmed cases of Lumpy Skin Disease reported.
  • The disease is debilitating and transmitted by insects.
  • Local veterinarians may implement control measures including quarantines and vaccinations.
  • Farmers are advised to vaccinate cattle and report any suspected cases.
  • Namibia exports beef globally, including to the EU and the US.
"LSD is a state-controlled disease, and wherever it occurs, it must be reported to the nearest state veterinarian." - Johannes Shoopala

This outbreak highlights the ongoing challenges faced by Namibia's livestock industry and the importance of disease control measures to protect herd health and export markets.
newTitle: 73 Cases of Lumpy Skin Disease Reported in Namibia

title: RKMH revises blood processing charge - The Arunachal Times
summary:
RKMH revises blood processing charge

Date: 17 Jan | Source: ITANAGAR

The Ramakrishna Mission Hospital (RKMH) has cut the processing charge for blood from Rs 500/unit to Rs 400/unit effective from 10 January, following recommendations from the State Blood Transfusion Council (SBTC).

  • The reduced charge pertains to the cost of testing blood for various infections, not the blood itself.
  • RKMH, a private charitable institute, requires these charges to sustain its transfusion facilities.
  • The SBTC warns against the sale or purchase of blood, highlighting it as a crime and urging vigilance against professional blood donation.
  • Government blood centers in Arunachal Pradesh provide blood free of cost subject to availability.
“Blood donation for any pecuniary advantage is a crime and the public in general is advised to keep a vigil...”

In conclusion, the move by RKMH aims to promote voluntary blood donation while ensuring the sustainability of testing facilities.
newTitle: RKMH Reduces Blood Processing Charge to Support Blood Donation Efforts

title: Drink Tea Every Day? Science Says It May Help You Age Slower - Woman's World
summary:
Drinking Tea Every Day May Slow Aging, Study Reveals

Publication Date: January 17, 2025 Source: Woman's World

A recent study suggests that consuming tea daily can slow down biological aging. This study, published in The Lancet Regional Health, involved over 13,000 participants from the UK and China.

  • The study finds that three cups of tea a day are optimal for slowing biological aging.
  • Significant differences were noted in participants who shifted from nondrinking to tea-drinking.
  • Polyphenols in tea are highlighted for their health benefits, including anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
  • Tea consumption may help protect against age-related diseases.
“Tea contains a variety of bioactive substances, especially polyphenols... which may delay the aging process,” the authors stated.

In conclusion, making tea a daily habit could offer significant health benefits and potentially extend lifespan by slowing aging processes.
newTitle: Drinking Tea Every Day May Slow Aging, Study Reveals

title: Experts call for urgent action against viral hepatitis - The Times of India
summary:
Experts call for urgent action against viral hepatitis

Publication Date: October 2023   Source: Health News

This article highlights the growing urgency for action against viral hepatitis as health experts emphasize the need for increased awareness, vaccination, and treatment accessibility.

  • Viral hepatitis is a significant public health issue affecting millions worldwide.
  • Experts are calling for better vaccination programs and public education campaigns.
  • Access to treatment remains a critical barrier in many regions.
  • The World Health Organization has set goals to eliminate viral hepatitis by 2030.
“Without immediate and coordinated action, we risk falling further behind in the fight against viral hepatitis,” said a health expert.

In conclusion, addressing viral hepatitis urgently could prevent millions of infections and improve global health outcomes.
newTitle: Experts call for urgent action against viral hepatitis

title: Minimally Invasive Approach Versus Traditional Approach for Treating Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis - Cureus
A nap can boost your cognition, here’s how - The Times of India
summary:
A Nap Can Boost Your Cognition, Here’s How

Published on: [Date not provided] | Source: [Source not provided]

In a fast-paced world, sleep often takes a back seat. However, even a short nap can significantly boost cognitive function and mood. Various studies support the positive effects of napping on memory and brain health.

  • A 2022 study found that a brief nap can improve memory to a degree similar to a full night's sleep.
  • A 2024 meta-analysis linked prolonged daytime napping with increased health risks, but napping under 30 minutes avoids these risks.
  • A 2023 study indicates napping may slow brain shrinkage associated with aging.
“Our findings suggest that, for some people, short daytime naps may be a part of the puzzle that could help preserve the health of the brain as we get older.” - Dr. Victoria Garfield

To maximize cognitive benefits while minimizing risks, naps should ideally last 20-30 minutes, taken in the afternoon, in a quiet environment, and can even be paired with a cup of coffee before sleeping for an added boost of alertness upon waking.
newTitle: A Nap Can Boost Your Cognition, Here’s How

title: With successful trials, CDRI a step closer to antimalarial vaccine - The Times of India
summary:
With successful trials, CDRI a step closer to antimalarial vaccine

Publication Date: N/A   Source: Times of India

The Central Drug Research Institute (CDRI) has reported successful trials of its antimalarial vaccine, promising a significant advancement in combating malaria.

  • The vaccine has shown efficacy in preclinical trials.
  • CDRI aims to address increasing malaria resistance to existing treatments.
  • The new vaccine presents hope for effective malaria prevention strategies.
"This development could revolutionize our approach to malaria prevention," said a CDRI spokesperson.

The progress made by CDRI in developing an antimalarial vaccine represents a hopeful step toward controlling malaria worldwide.
newTitle: CDRI Moves Closer to Developing an Antimalarial Vaccine Following Successful Trials
